title: brexit news jacob rees mogg david lammy irish border donald tusk european union
story: The political heavyweights clashed on social media over the Irish border, which has proved to be a log-jam in Brexit negotiations.It came after EU Council President, Donald Tusk, confirmed on Twitter the EU was going to offer the UK a Canada style Brexit deal.Mr Rees-Mogg, head of the European Research Group (ERG), replied: &ldquoThis is a good solution for everyone and the ERG's proposals for the Irish border mean it could work for the UK as a whole.But David Lammy, arch-Remainer and Labour MP for Tottenham, retorted with a furious tirade against the Somerset MP.                Brexiteer RIDICULES 'classic scaremongering' used by Remainers                 Raab's KEY reason why second Brexit referendum would be IRRESPONSIBLEMr Lammy said: &ldquoWe've had quite enough of your proposals for the Irish border.&ldquoYou're on tape calling for people to be &lsquoinspected&rsquo as they were &lsquoduring the Troubles&rsquo.&ldquoThis disdain for the Good Friday agreement is shameful and no solution at all.Lots of social media users agreed with the Remainer&rsquos reply.The political heavyweights clashed on social media (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg praised Donald Tusk (Image: )                Brexit: Varadkar tells UK to reveal new backstop before October summit                Gibraltar Minister outlines why Spain NEEDS a Brexit deal with BritainOne said: &ldquoNobody will be 'inspecting' me in my own country.Another added: &ldquoYou are so right David to imperil peace as if it were a trifle totally unacceptable.And another accused the Brexiteer of wanting to return to the troubles, saying: &ldquoMogg misses the war.But others leapt to Mr Rees-Mogg&rsquos defence.Donald Tusk, confirmed on Twitter the EU was going to offer the UK a Canada style Brexit deal (Image: )A woman from Derry replied to Mr Lammy saying: &ldquoHere's a novel idea: how about asking the peeps ACTUALLY LIVING in NI for their opinion?Another social media user, from England, said: &ldquoLammy is a troublemaker and rabble rouser. He doesn't want solutions or constructive dialogue.&ldquoWe agree with the EU President and will work with him.And another added: &ldquoWrong again David Lammy, the Moggster wipes the floor with you every time, any day of the week!The European Council President envisaged a future relationship with the UK as a &ldquoCanada plus plus plus arrangement, which could be &ldquomuch further reaching on trade, internal security and on foreign cooperation.He added: &ldquoThis is a true measure of respect. And this offer remains in place. The EU is serious about getting the best possible deal.&ldquoEven though we haven&rsquot changed our minds that the consequences of Brexit will be negative, for both sides.The EU's chief negotiator Michel Barnier has previously spoken of the possibility of such a deal being pursued, but critics in the UK believe it doesn't fully address the Irish border.Brussels is now hoping the end of the Conservative party conference will bring a fresh attitude to talks as both sides strive to complete a deal on the Irish border as early as the upcoming October summit and the rest of the withdrawal deal by November.

title: Royal wedding 2018 date dress October Princess Eugenie Meghan Markle
story: Princess Eugenie, 28, the Queen&rsquos sixth grandchild, will marry the wine merchant fianc&eacute on Friday, October 12.Luxury wedding dress designer Caroline Castigliano believes Eugenie will opt for a &ldquobeautifully fitted and &ldquo50s classic style dress, rather than the sleek and sculpted dress chosen by Meghan Markle for her wedding to Prince Harry in May.Ms Castigliano told Express: &ldquoI think she will have quite a floaty sort of skirt. I think when she has worn 50s style dresses if you look back, I think she wore one for the races. They are the sort of styling that really suits her figure.She added: &ldquoI think 50s is quite fashionable right now if I am perfectly honest with you.                Royal Wedding preparations: Windsor prepares for Eugenie's day &ldquoI think it&rsquoll be simple but I think she might have some lace in it. I think that it will be sort of 50s contemporary modern if you want to look at it like that.&ldquoBut it is not going to be a fashion dress and it is going to be nothing like Meghan&rsquos.The London-based designer also believes the dress will not be like Kate, the Duchess of Cambridge&rsquos dress.Ms Castigliano said: &ldquoNo, I think Kate&rsquos is, what I call, just a traditional wedding dress. Kate&rsquos was clear tradition, high neck, long lace sleeves.Royal Wedding 2018: Princess Eugenie likely to wear romantic 50s style dress, says designer (Image: )&ldquoI won&rsquot be surprised if she does have a sleeve but I don&rsquot think it is necessary. She might well be in strapless. But I think she will be much more floaty, much more romantic. Just much more of that softness and of that young girl romance.Eugenie and her sister Beatrice are well known for their eclectic style. But the wedding dress designer said Eugenie is likely to follow royal tradition with her gown with an added modern twist.Ms Castigliano said: &ldquoIt seems that everybody just falls into the line of protocol.&ldquoSo it is highly likely she will wear a sleeve. And I can only imagine that she maybe will wear a sleeve and if she does change or maybe she&rsquoll have a dress that can be adapted so that she maybe will be able to take the sleeves off so that she has a strapless dress in the evening.&ldquoAnd she has got lovely skin and a beautiful bust line. She&rsquod look beautiful in a strapless dress that would cut well.The ceremony will take place at St George&rsquos Chapel in Windsor Castle, the same venue that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle said their vows in May.Over 850 guests have allegedly been invited &ndash more than St George&rsquos chapel 800 person capacity allows.The celebration will last for two days, with the second day more casual and a high celebrity turn-out expected.The wedding will be broadcast as part of a special edition of ITV&rsquos This Morning show.The lavish nuptials are set to cost the British taxpayer an eye-watering &pound2.7million, according to Royal expert Hamish Shephard.He said security will cost &pound2million, floristry &pound100,000, music &pound25,000 and the dress &pound200,000.

story: Royal Lodge is brimming with royal history (Image: )The sprawling Royal Lodge in Windsor has been passed down from generations among the royal family for hundreds of years until at the turn of the Millennium Prince Andrew and then-wife Sarah Ferguson acquired it.Their daughter, 28-year-old Princess Eugenie, had her pick of venues to host her wedding reception to wine merchant Jack Brooksbank, 32, yet requested her old home for her second party, which takes place after the Queen hosts the initial after wedding event.It will also be the site of a third bash which the Duchess of York is throwing the day after her wedding on Saturday, October 13.With the huge property overlooking the 21 acres of gardens and woodland which became a playground for royal children through the decades, the secluded mansion will no doubt provide the perfect backdrop to a fairytale wedding fit for a princess.                Princess Beatrice of York in pictures: HRH looks glam on night outThe sprawling Royal Lodge in Windsor has been passed down from generations among the royals (Image: )                Royal wedding: Princess Eugenie's dress will be NOTHING like Meghan's                ITV reveals official hashtag for Princess Eugenie&rsquos weddingIn photograph taken from 1954, a young Prince Charles is seen climbing a tree  (Image: )                Royal wedding: How Fergie will make sure Diana is present at wedding                Princess Eugenie wedding: What time does Eugenie&rsquos wedding start? Royal Lodge is brimming with royal history having been the location Princess Margaret and Antony Armstrong-Jones - who bears a striking resemblance to Mr Brooksbank - announced their engagement in 1960.Pictured in front of the fireplace peppered with royal memorabilia, an effortlessly glamorous Margaret casually drops her foot to the side and folds her arms next to a rigid-looking Lord Snowdon in their black and white engagement photo.In another in colour image, the couple are pictured on the grounds of the 30-bedroom property looking towards the camera while the residence is seen in the distance.Express has unearthed candid photographs from inside Royal Lodge giving a fascinating insight of regal life inside the Windsor grounds.                Royal Wedding: Which route will Princess Eugenie's procession take?                Princess Eugenie wedding: What time does Eugenie&rsquos wedding start? Margaret casually drops her foot to the side and folds her arms (Image: )                Will Meghan, Harry, Kate and William attend Princess Eugenie's wedding                Princess Eugenie wedding on TV: Will wedding be televised? Prince Andrew spent &pound7.5million renovating the Georgian property (Image: )                Will Eugenie change her name and title when she marries 'COMMONER'                Royal Wedding: Which route will Princess Eugenie's procession take?In photograph taken from 1954, a young Prince Charles is seen climbing a tree in front of Royal Lodge while is sister, Princess Anne, pics daffodils on the ground beneath him.In another stunning photograph, the Queen is pictured with her father, King George VI, six years before his death in 1952.He is pictured in the garden of Royal Lodge in a simple brown suit, blue shirt and tie on bamboo garden furniture with his wife, the Queen mother, as well as princess Margaret and a then-Princess Elizabeth.The four are also photographed outside the front of the impressive Royal Lodge with three dogs.The lodge has 21 acres of private grounds and eight separate properties for staff (Image: )                Will Eugenie change her name and title when she marries 'COMMONER'                Royal Wedding: Which route will Princess Eugenie's procession take?Four years before, Princess Elizabeth is seen at the window of the lodge playing the piano. Portraits and books surround her as well as two empty chairs facing one another, suggesting whoever was sat there had not wanted to be photographed.In a grand black and white, the ivy-clad Royal Lodge is photographed from the front.In a final picture, Y Bwthyn Bach stands in the background of an image of the grounds. The cottage was gifted to the Queen and Princess Margaret and has been renovated by Princess Beatrice.Today, Royal Lodge serves as the residence of the Duke of York who moved into the property in 2004 with Sarah Ferguson and their daughters Eugenie and Beatrice, despite the couple orcing in 1996.                Princess Eugenie wedding: The Queen lends venue to granddaughter                Was Princess Eugenie&rsquos wedding snubbed by BBC? Eugenie will wed Mr Brooksbank on October 12  (Image: )Prince Andrew spent &pound7.5million renovating the Georgian property to add a swimming pool and driving range to the grounds.The lodge has 21 acres of private grounds and eight separate properties for staff to live in.It is not open to the public.Eugenie will wed Mr Brooksbank on October 12 and the Queen will throw her a first reception on the grounds of Windsor Castle.

title: Brexit news Gerard Batten Theresa May speech deal latest UK EU withdrawal
story: The incensed British MEP insisted the Prime Minister had undermined the progress of the Brexit negotiations with her unwillingness to share the details of her demands.Mr Batten appeared unimpressed with Theresa May's speech at the Tory Party Conference on Wednesday, putting into question her ability to deliver a withdrawal deal with the European Union after backing Remain at the 2016 referendum.Speaking to RT UK, the leader of Ukip said: How can we trust her? She was a Remainer up until the day of the referendum.Why would you believe anything she says? You can only judge her on results and so far there haven&rsquot been any results.                Lord Sugar launches SCATHING DIG at Brexit in Apprentice opener                Farage warns THIS aspect of May's speech signals Brexit to get worseMr Batten suggested the&nbspfailure to propose a deal based on a pre-existing EU trade deal with other non-EU countries had put in jeopardy the successful conclusion of talks with Brussels.He also claimed Mrs May had done little to have the bloc respect her during the negotiations, further decreasing the chances of a new arrangement.He continued: There are two things I&rsquod like to pick up on, one was talking about offering the EU a free trade deal. Well, yeah, why doesn&rsquot she do that?She could say to them &lsquolet&rsquos have continued free trade.&rsquo You have 58 free trade agreements with countries around the world, none of them include the free movement of people, and she could have said &lsquowell, you&rsquove got plenty of these on the shelf, we can customise one pretty quickly, you can make your mind up about it. We can have one of those or you can have WTO terms.&rsquoBrexit news: Mr Batten put into question Mrs May's ability to deliver Brexit (Image: BBC&bullRT UK)Why doesn&rsquot she do that? She talks about seeking respect from the EU, that&rsquos the other thing. Why would they respect you if you are not actually telling them what it is that you intend to do and you keep on asking &lsquohow do we leave, can we have this?&rsquoThey&rsquore not going to respect somebody like that.Prime Minister used her speech to issue a rallying cry for ministers to unite and back her plan following weeks of party feuding.According to Bloomberg, Mrs May wants to rush her final Brexit deal through Parliament in weeks in an attempt to fight off opposition to it from her Conservative Party.                Brexit MIRACLE: Rees-Mogg, Farage and Tusk JOIN SIDES                May faces &lsquo&pound20 BILLION SHORTFALL&rsquo if she aims to &lsquoEND AUSTERITY'Brexit news: A confident-looking Mrs May kickstarted her speech dancing to ABBA (Image: )People familiar with the matter have reportedly said her team wants the final withdrawal agreement signed off by lawmakers within two weeks of the terms being agreed with the European Union.This would see Parliament vote on whether to accept or decline her proposals by the beginning of December following a summit of EU leaders on the weekend of November 17-18.Ministers believe reaching a deal quickly will provide enough time to pass important legislation through Parliament before the UK exits the bloc on March 29.The pound rose on Thursday following a report Ireland is backing Theresa May's plan for an all-customs union with the EU.Sterling had fallen to $1.2922 overnight - its weakest since September 10 - but recovered to increase 0.2 percent to $1.2967 and 88.61 versus the euro.

title: Brexit news Galileo satellite system UK EU withdrawal airbus latest Barnier
story: The British CEO appeared positive about the global prospects of the British space sector after Brexit.The European Union has threatened to stop Britain from using the shared Galileo satellite system after its withdrawal from the bloc due to security risks but Mr Martin insisted there are opportunities for the country all around the world.Mr Martin told Sky News his company has already begun to seek new commercial partnership with non-EU countries: I am bullish. The great thing about space is that it&rsquos a global industry.When you think about the way satellites work, floating around the whole world, you can do business anywhere. We want to maintain a strong relationship with Europe but we are already looking at opportunities in North America, South America, Australasia, Asia.                WE&rsquoLL DO IT OURSELVES! UK space team issue WARNING to BrusselsThe chief executive also suggested British companies will explore new opportunities even faster after the UK ultimately breaks off ties with Brussels in March 2019.Mr Martin added: That will continue and that will accelerate even faster.Figures published on August 9 suggested the UK could compete for contracts to launch an estimated 2,000 small satellites by 2030 thanks to the burgeoning British space sector.The data also suggests Britain is well placed to thrive even if the European Union does deny the country access to the Galileo satellite system after Brexit.Brexit news: The satellite company boss said he felt bullish about the prospect for the sector (Image: &bullSKY NEWS)EU Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier threatened to cut the UK&rsquos access to the Galileo system after its withdrawal from the bloc despite the &pound1billion contributions to the overall &pound8.5billion costs.Airbus Defence and Space, the aerospace company at the forefront of much of the technology which is powering the Galileo satellite system, said they are ready to deliver a rival system if Brussels follows through on threats to exclude Britain after Brexit.Business development director Andrew Stroomer told Express he has no doubt his team has the know-how to build a stand-alone satellite navigation system out of a facility which currently builds an impressive 25 percent of the world&rsquos telecommunications satellites.Mr Stroomer said: &ldquoWe would like Galileo to continue with the participation of the UK but if you look at Galileo, the UK has contributed some of the most complicated parts of that.&ldquoWe don&rsquot do everything &ndash but we do enough to show we are capable of building such a system for the UK. From an industry point of view, we have the capability.&ldquoThere would not be a conflict of interest. It would mean working with the UK government as a customer.

title: Brexit news Andrew Rosendell second referendum UK EU withdrawal latest Theresa May
story: The Tory MP argued British voters had first backed plans to Brexit when they re-elected David Cameron during the 2015 General Election.Mr Rosindell said the 2015 vote, followed by the European Union referendum in 2016 and Parliament voting to trigger Article 50 the following year served as proof to show Britons do not want a new vote.Speaking to Sky News, the Romford MP said: You&rsquore introducing something completely new to the whole situation. We had a general election in 2015.David Cameron won on the basis of an in-out referendum. We then passed Article 50 through Parliament, now we have passed the EU Withdrawal Bill. We had the biggest vote of the British people in history for this.                'Can we trust Theresa May?' UK MEP in SCATHING attack after speech                Wetherspoons boss SHUTS DOWN Remain campaigner with this simple pointMr Rosendell warned Remainers trying to pressure the Government into holding a fresh vote could not expect to be successful without an election and a manifesto,: The Government won&rsquot support it so how on Earth can you bring legislation forward?The Tory MP insisted he still felt confident Theresa May will help deliver the Brexit voters wanted but urged her to rethink her Chequers plan to ensure she has the support of her party.The Prime Minister has been under increased scrutiny over her Brexit white paper, with MP James Duddridge penning a letter of no-confidence in Mrs May after she reiterated her plans to maintain her negotiating strategy throughout the last phase of talks with Brussels.He continued: I&rsquom confident that things will work out and that&rsquos why I&rsquom supporting her to get on with the job.Brexit news: Mr Rosindell said Britons had repeatedly voted to leave the EU (Image: SKY NEWS&bull)I want her to rethink some of these issues but I do believe we are edging towards a successful outcome and when it goes through Parliament when we leave the EU, I think we&rsquoll be sitting here in a year or two&rsquos time and wonder what this was all about.Mr Rosendell added: It will all come to nothing, our trading cooperation with Europe will be as strong as ever but we&rsquoll be once again a free and independent nation.Mr Duddridge announced on Wednesday he had submitted a no-confidence letter in Mrs May to 1922 Committee chairman Graham Brady demanding a proper leadership election.In his letter, the Tory MP said: Please accept this email as a letter of no confidence in Theresa May.I am normally a loyalist, served the Whip Office for nearly 5 years and have never voted against the Government. However, there comes a point that blind loyalty is nor the right way forward.Mr Duddridge claimed the Prime Minister is incapable of delivering the Brexit Britons demanded during the 2016 EU referendum and a new leader would help the party hold on to power.

story: Shadow communities and local government secretary Andrew Gwynne faced a brutal grilling by Brexit supporting businessman Richard Tice, who accused the Labour MP of &ldquoclassic scaremongering.Mr Gwynne told LBC: &ldquoI think it is absolutely crucial that in our negotiations, as we are leaving the European Union, that we do not water down our food safety laws.&ldquoI would be very concerned if that was being proposed. So, let&rsquos just get that out of the way.&ldquoThe second thing is, we do hope that your consumers have at least the opportunity &ndash we are not going to force feed anyone &ndash but at least have the opportunity to invest in an American turkey or chicken or any other piece of protein that might be of their choosing.&ldquoAs for chlorinated chicken, I am sick and tired of hearing about chlorinated chicken because it is not true.

title: Brexit news UK unemployment eurozone unemployment eurostat data
story: The statistical office, called Eurostat, released its unemployment data for August this year which put the Eurozone&rsquos unemployment rate at 8.1 percent.Meanwhile, the UK&rsquos has fallen to just 4 percent, the lowest it has been since 1975, as Britain&rsquos Brexit economic boom continues.The figures mean the Eurozone&rsquos average unemployment is more than double the UK&rsquos, although the figure is being dragged up by the struggling economies of countries like Greece (19.1 percent unemployment) and Spain (15.2 percent).Commenting on the UK&rsquos low unemployment rate, Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey, said: &ldquoWith the unemployment rate falling further to just 4 percent and youth unemployment down over 45 percent since 2010, school leavers can look forward to a growing jobs market, improving the prospects for their future careers.                Brexit news: EU exit to 'boost demand' for UK apprentices                FINANCIAL CRASH WARNING: World economy 'VULNERABLE to SECOND Great ...&ldquoIn fact, the UK&rsquos vibrant jobs market is benefiting people across the board.&ldquoRecord rates of ethnic minority people in work also show that more families across our society are benefiting from the security of a job.&ldquoWe have some of the most creative, innovative and hard-working young people in the world and this summer I&rsquove been urging them to take on a summer job, gaining &lsquosoft skills&rsquo - or as I call them, essential skills - for their future career.Parts of the Eurozone are still struggling to recover from the 2008 economic crash, with the employment rate slow to pick up in the aftermath.The UK's unemployment rate is half that of the Eurozones, and around 13 lower than the EU's (Image: )Esther McVey is optimistic about the future of the UK economy (Image: )Greece emerged from its eight-year financial bailout in August this year after successfully completing its third emergency loan programme.Whilst conditions are improving for the country, its economy is still much smaller than when its debt crisis started and it owes hundreds of billions of euros to the EU, IMF and Germany.The EU as a whole has an unemployment rate of 6.8 percent, being lower than the Eurozone&rsquos with the inclusion of countries like the UK, Czech Republic (2.5 percent) and Poland (4 percent).According to the Office for National Statistics, the UK has 65,000 fewer jobless people since March, taking the total number down to 1.36million.                Greece just launched its budget for 2019 Retirees demonstration against austerity measures in Greece (Image: )At the same time, 32.9million people are in work, 42,000 more than in the last quarter.Wages have increased by 2.7 percent (excluding bonuses) without accounting for inflation and increased 0.4 percent (excluding bonuses) in real terms.Britain's strong economic performance continues to thwart Remainer attempts to undermine the economy with Project Fear doomsaying about Brexit.The CBI, which has been outspoken against Brexit, has admitted some of their assumptions were wrong.President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker and the UK's Prime Minister Theresa May (Image: )Head of Economic Intelligence at the CBI, Anna Leach, said: &ldquoThe labour market continues to confound expectations of a slowdown, with employment rate at another record high and the unemployment rate the lowest since the 1970s.&ldquoBut, despite high vacancies, pay growth has slipped to a six-month low, keeping up the pressure on people&rsquos living standards.Youth unemployment rate is up at 11 percent compared to the previous month's 10.9, although its general trajectory has been downwards.The number of young people looking for work is down 45 percent since 2010.

title: Big Ben restoration work chime first time date
story: The bong is back! Big Ben will chime again next week (Image: )The chimes were stopped temporarily in August last year for the safety of workers restoring the Elizabeth Tower, home to the Great Clock and Great Bell (otherwise known as Big Ben).The bong, which usually sounds every hour, is back only for a few special occasions during the course of the work, such as Christmas last year.The bell will ring out on Thursday next week between 8pm and 10pm to test it ahead of Remembrance Sunday and New Year&rsquos Eve.Labour MP Stephen Pound, who was vehemently against the silencing of the bells, said: &ldquoRemembrance Sunday is a solemn occasion and the sonorous sound of the bells will certainly add to the sense of occasion.                I hope the Queen likes it! Artist unveils stained glass window tribute&ldquoI salute the courage of the Bell Master who agreed to let this happen and let the chimes of freedom ring out again over the city.The Elizabeth Tower, the most photographed building in Britain, is currently going through thorough and complex conservation work to safeguard it for future generations.Big Ben is usually accompanied by four quarter bells, which chime every fifteen minutes, but only Big Ben will ring out on the special occasions this year.All the bells have been temporarily disconnected from the clock mechanism and the weights lowered to the base of the tower.The clock tower is the most iconic building in London (Image: )A bespoke electric mechanism has been built to power the striking hammer as a temporary way of sounding the bell in order to mark the special events.The striking bell is a huge 200kg tool used to hit the 13,760kg bell, which chimes to the note of E natural.Steve Jaggs, keeper of the clock, said last year: &ldquoI have the great honour of ensuring this beautiful piece of Victorian engineering is in tip top condition on a daily basis.                Terror strike on Parliament &lsquocould kill more than 100 MPs in minutes'                MPs&rsquo fury as repairs at scandal-hit office building go through the ...Vintage engraving of the Bell Big Ben in the Clock Tower of Westminster, (Image: )&ldquoThis essential programme of works will safeguard the clock on a long-term basis as well as protecting and preserving its home - the Elizabeth Tower.Big Ben has marked each hour almost unbroken for 157 years, except for maintenance and refurbishment in 2007 and between 1983 and 1985.The Elizabeth Tower is part of the Grade-1 UNESCO World Heritage site that is the Palace of Westminster.

title: unilever share price uk netherlands company move
story: The British-Dutch consumer goods group which produces brands such as Persil, Marmite and Sure had proposed to move its headquarters to Rotterdam as part of a restructuring plan.However, many of Unilever&rsquos largest shareholders did not want the firm to move and even warned it would leave UK investors with a hefty tax bill.A spokesman for Unilever said: &ldquoIn developing the proposal, the board was guided by the opportunity to unlock value for our shareholders by creating a stronger, simpler and more competitive Unilever that is better positioned for long-term success.&ldquoWe have had an extensive period of engagement with shareholders and have received widespread support for the principle behind simplification.                Brexiteer shuts down pessimistic predictions with this brilliant point                Pressure spreads to block Unilever moveHowever, we recognise that the proposal has not received support from a significant group of shareholders and therefore consider it appropriate to withdraw.Many shareholders including Aviva Investors and M&ampG had publicly come out against Unilever&rsquos plan to move its headquarters to Rotterdam.Certain UK investors were concerned that the &pound124 billion company would be removed from the FTSE 100.Chairman Marijn Dekkers&nbspsaid: Unilever has built a long track record of consistent and competitive performance.Unilever will not move to Rotterdam but its HQ will stay in London (Image:  )Unilever produces many of the popular household brands  (Image: )The board continues to believe that simplifying our dual-headed structure would, over time, provide opportunities to further accelerate value creation and serve the best long-term interests of Unilever.The board will now consider its next steps and will continue to engage with our shareholders.&ldquoWe will proceed with the plan to cancel the NV preference shares, further strengthening our corporate governance.Top shareholders lashed out at Unilever's proposal to move to Rotterdam  (Image: )Unilever employs around 169,000 people around the world, which includes 7,300 in the UK.Unite national officer Rhys McCarthy said: &ldquoInvestors understand the need for great British-based companies like&nbspUnilever&nbspto retain their headquarters in the UK.&ldquoThe UK&rsquos weak takeover rules which put short-termism ahead of the long term are clearly a major factor in Unilever&rsquos proposed move following a failed hostile takeover bid, as is the swirling uncertainty around Brexit.&ldquoMinisters need to get a grip on Brexit and toughen takeover rules to stop more firms like Unilever seeking to flee overseas.

title: Brexit news Chuka Umunna UK remain EU latest second referendum Theresa May
story: The Streatham MP candidly admitted he still believes the Brexit process can be reverted and Britain could stay in the European Union.&nbspChuka Umunna has repeatedly spoken out against the British Government's plans to break up from Brussels and has become a vocal supporter of the People's Vote campaign calling for a second Brexit referendum.The arch-Remainer shared his views as he talked about the future of the Conservative Party after the EU leaves the bloc on BBC This Week: I think they probably will want to start afresh but the problem is they are never going to be able to run away from Brexit.If Brexit happens &ndash which is a big if, I don&rsquot accept it is inevitable &ndash your approach to Brexit will become part of your economic policy whether you like it or not. However, there comes a point that blind loyalty is nor the right way forward.But last week, pro-Brexit MP Henry Smith told Express an immediate change of leader would not give Britain the country the certainty it needs and any challenge should be postponed to Summer 2019.Mr Smith said: I don&rsquot think seeking to change the leader right now is probably in the national interest although I think we could&rsquove had a stronger negotiating position with somebody else.That is very difficult but I don&rsquot think the Prime Minister, Theresa May, can continue leading this party much beyond the exit date of 29 March. story: Commuters struggle to get to work this morning in London  (Image: Twitter @kurmeraki* @MrNickPearmain)There will be no services running on the Central Line today, Friday October 5, and the Waterloo and City Line is running but with severe delays.Normal service is not set to resume on the affected lines until mid-morning on Saturday.The 800,000 passengers who use the Central Line daily are being forced to use other lines.Tube user Its Georgio tweeted: &ldquoTube strike really holds London hostage! We remain open for discussions on how to resolve this dispute, and apologise to our customers for the unnecessary disruption.Commuters have taken to Twitter to vent their frustration at the Central Line not working.A petition has been launched in a bid to stop further strikes  (Image:  )Cara Wood tweeted: &ldquoThe nightmare that&rsquos caused when the Central Line strikes is not fun.Linda Alexander tweeted: &ldquoNo Central Line this morning due to industrial action, so drove to Stratford to pick the Jubilee line to complete my journey. title: metoo Del Boy Marlene only fools and horses tv comedy
story: Sue, 69, who became a household name as Boycie's flirtatious wife Marlene, said Del Boy and other characters could not get away with the same antics now that made the TV show such a success in the Eighties.She said: The very first episode Del gave me a big hug, kissed me fondly and pinched my bum and nobody took any offence at it, except Boycie, who looked daggers.Every time we met that would happen. It's quite fun.I don't think you would get away with Del Boy pinching Marlene's bottom without everybody saying 'He's a pervert and that shouldn't be allowed and he should be locked-up'.                Wolf whistle: Intimidating or flattering?                Wolf-whistling could considered a HATE CRIME to try and tackle sexi...Sue, who starred alongside Sir David Jason as Del Boy and Nicholas Lyndhurst as Rodney, added that men don't know how to behave now because almost anything can be deemed inappropriate.She said: A wolf whistle isn't supposed to be allowed now, which I think is such a pity. It has gone too far. I'm sure it will swing back and eventually we'll be able to flirt away again, but at the moment I don't think it's possible.There have been people saying you could never make Only Fools And Horses now, that it was racist. It wasn't remotely racist.Del and Rodney and all that community, there wasn't a racist ounce in their bodies.Del Boy (c), Grandad (L) and Rodney in Only Fools and Horses (Image: )However, she said that she welcomed the increased respect with which women are now treated, particularly over pay.Sue said: I'm absolutely with the MeToo movement. Of course women should be paid as much as men. I'm praying that there will be more parts written for women, which is happening.I was paid much, much less than John Challis (Boycie) on Only Fools And Horses.She said it was only when the two appeared together in a spin-off show, The Green Green Grass, that the BBC did the decent thing and we got parity. It's been the most wonderful job.Sue will appear in three episodes as a orced woman who is very disappointed in love and has been very badly let down by her Italian husband. She added: It's clear that she is not planning to be single for very long.Only Fools And Horses was created and written by John Sullivan over seven series from 1981 to 1991. Its Christmas specials continued until 2003.Still Open All Hours is on Sunday at 8.30pm on BBC One.

story: While it can make the landscape look somewhat magical, not a lot of people actually know how fog is formed and how it dfers from mist.Fog is like a low-level cloud that originates from a local body of water - such as a lake, marsh or the sea.It dfers from regular clouds because it contains water droplets from a number of dferent sources.When water vapour in the air condenses into tiny droplets of liquid water, they stay suspended in the air and fog is formed.Fog contains up to . ml of water per cubic metre.If you were to fill an Olympic sized swimming pool with fog and then somehow condense it, you would be left with around . litres of water - just over  pints.The foggiest place in the world is an area of the Atlantic Ocean called Grand Banks off the coast of Newfoundland.The area forms the meeting place of the cold Labrador Current from the north and the much warmer Gulf Stream from the south.This creates over  days of fog every year.Fog warnings are often issued when driving conditions are dficult and dangerous.Fogs are generally named after the physical process that takes place to produce them.The main types of fog are as follows.This type of fog usually appears in the winter and is aided by clear skies and calm weather.The cooling of land overnight by thermal radiation cools the air close to the surface.This reduces the ability of the air to hold moisture and allows condensation and fog to occur.Radiation fogs usually disappear as the ground warms after sunrise.Freezing fog is made up of supercooled water droplets which remain liquid even though the temperature is below freezing point.One of the characteristics of freezing fog is that rime - made-up of feathery crystals - is deposited on the windward side of surfaces such as lampposts, pylons and transmitting masts.Valley fog forms where cold dense air settles into the lower parts of the valley condensing and forming fog.It is usually a result of warm air passing over the valley.It can last for several days during calm conditions in winter.This type of fog occurs when most air passes over a cool surface and is cooled.A common example of this is when a warm front passes over an area with snow cover.It is also common at sea when moist tropical air moves over cooler waters.If the wind blows in the right direction then sea fog can become transported over coastal land areas.Upslope fog or hill fog forms when winds blow air up a slope.The air cools as it rises and allows moisture in it to condense.This type of fog is caused by cold air passing over warmer water or moist land.It often causes freezing fog and sometimes frost.When warm water evaporates into the low air this type of fog occurs.The only dference between mist and fog is visibility.It is called fog when visibility is km or less.In driving terms it tends to be referred to as fog when visibility is m or less.According to the Highway Code, you have to use headlights when visibility is seriously reduced - generally defined as less than  metres .The AA recommends you take your time, keep a greater distance between you and the car in front and keep your front and rear fog lights on.You should be aware of how to operate your fog lights, and take care not to rely too much on automatic lighting.If you get to a junction and you cant see properly due to fog, stop and roll your windows down to listen to traffic.Fog is responsible for a rare weather phenomenon called a fog dome.The white bulbs are caused by a source of heat close to the ground that forces fog to lt away into a dome as warm air rises like a hot air balloon.Fog also has its own rainbows called a fog bow, which look like a normal rainbow but are just plain white.They are made up of tiny water droplets that are so small, they white-wash the fog bow.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. But WE’RE in danger of souring relations.Give it a rest, EU fools.HOW appalling that the sisters of terror victim cop Keith Palmer have no Legal Aid to pursue the truth at his inquest.Michelle Palmer and Angela Clark want to hire an independent expert to assess whether a permanent armed presence at Parliament’s Carriage Gates entrance might have saved their brother.But the Legal Aid Agency hasn’t processed their application. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
