title: haunting photos reveal life inside
story: NewsHaunting photos reveal le inside Nazi PoW camp caught on film by British soldier with camera hidden in BibleThe images were captured by Terry Hunt - his fate is not known but the photos survived in an album compiled by fellow prisoner of war David CourtneyShareByAdam Aspinall:,  OCT NewsThe burial of a British prisoner who was shot by German guards "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTo the German guards, PoW Terry Hunt would have seemed a devout man of faith, seldom seen around the squalid, overcrowded camp without his holy Bible. If they had known a camera was hidden inside that Bible and that he was taking these incredible pictures of le inside Stalag Luft IVB, Terry would almost certainly have been executed. His ultimate fate is unknown but the images he took survive in an album compiled by fellow PoW David Courtney. In one shot, French prisoners bow their heads in prayer at a church service, while another shows row upon row of tents that were home to many of the , inmates near Muhlberg in Saxony. At the funeral of a British serviceman who was executed, possibly for trying to escape, a dozen German soldiers are pictured firing their rles in a respectful salute over the airman’s coffin – despite being responsible for his death.  On a more light-hearted note, another photo shows a group of men all dressed – convincingly – as women for a theatrical prodshyshyuction staged to keep up morale in the camp. But for Russian PoWs there was precious little to laugh about. One photo captioned “swap shop” shows Brits exchanging unwanted food for cigarettes, while starving Russians rummage through empty cans for food. Russians are also seen queuing to get soup from the British prisoners, one holding out his cap for potato peelings.  Terry Hunt had been a film cameraman before the war and went on RAF sorties to make newsreels. He was dressed as an RAF sergeant in case he was ever captured, which he was after his plane was shot down. The album includes a picture of him with the covert camera, perhaps taken by Courtney, who was in the RAF’s  Squadron when his Halax bomber was shot down near Berlin in January . Stalag IVB opened in September  and when it was liberated by Soviet troops in April , there were about , inmates, , of them British.

title: psychopath who dug up childrens
story: NewsPsychopath who dug up childrens bodies to turn them into dolls deemed HARMLESS by medical expertsWARNING: DISTRESSING IMAGES. Anatoly Moskvin dug up then mummied the girls who were all aged between three and  years oldShareCommentsByZoey McDougallKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video glimpse-inside-home-man-who-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA twisted man who admitted to digging up the bodies of  young girls and turning them into dolls has been deemed harmless by medical experts. Anatoly Moskvin dug up the mummied the girls who were all aged between three and -years-old. The -year-old even dressed them in knee- boots, stockings and clothes, before putting make-up on their faces. He also wedged music boxes inside their rib cages. Journalist Moskvin was caught some six years ago as he was the main suspect for vandalising Muslim cemeteries in the city of Nizhny Novgorod in western Russia.  But when the cops entered his flat, where he lived with his parents, they were shocked to find  mummied dolls of the dead little girls. He reportedly spent almost a decade living with some of the corpses, with the families of the girls not realising the coffins of their children had been empty for a long time. He has confessed to  counts of digging up the graves and abusing the little girls in them and later told police that he was in fact waiting for science to find ways of resuscitating them. He has spent the last five of years in a mental hospital where he was receiving mandatory treatment but his doctors are now said to believe Moskvin is ready to go home. The medical experts are reportedly convinced he is no longer dangerous. Another medical exam is reportedly due to take place and the next court hearing on Moskvins case is scheduled for October .  Ten-year-old Olga Chardymovas body was one the girls stolen from what was supposed to be her final resting place. Olgas mother, Natalia Chardymova, , is outraged at the official request made to release the evil man from his secure psychiatric hospital. Natalia - who now has a son aged nine - said she was appalled that Moskvin could be freed. “This creature brought fear, terror and panic into my ,” she said. “I shudder to think that he will have freedom to go where he wants.” He had warned the court that ‘I willto my girls’,he was ever freed, she said. But this now seems forgotten. “Neither my family nor the families of the other victims will be able to sleep peacefully. “He needs to be kept under surveillance. “I insist on a le sentence….only under medical supervision, without the right of free movement.  “Years have passed but my attitude to Moskvin has not changed at all - horror, fear and panic. “Hell cause a lot more suffering to someone ….” Natalia said she feels “shock, horror and fear - even my voice trembles now as I speak.” She said: “These are my fears, my worries… I don’t want repetition of what happened in the past. “It was very scary.” However, it is believed the court is unlikely to seek the views of bereaved parents. “He deprived me of the right to visit my daughter, to visit her grave: as it turned out, for years I visited an empty coffin,” she added. Little Olga was murdered in . She had begged her mother to be allowed to walk on her own to her granny’s flat in the next apartment block. Im ten already. I can go myself, she pleaded. Natalia relented and Olga went out with her favourite green bag and blue umbrella, never to be seen alive again. A drug addict waiting in the lobby of her block had forced her back up to the top floor, and robbed her of her earrings, and because she tried to escape, cracked her over the head with a metal bar. Despite searches for her body, Olgas remains with the umbrella and bag were not found for five months wedged behind pipes in the blocks attic. We buried her on  October , Natalia said.  “I could never imagine that almost exactly ten years later, on the  October , I would open her grave with the police, and find her remains had vanished. Her coffin was empty, with a hole at the top from which he had pulled the remains. You cant begin to imagine it, that somebody would touch the grave of your child, the most holy place in this world for you.” She added: My girl had been murdered,anyone deserved to rest in peace, she did, but instead her grave had been robbed.” I still find it hard to grasp the scale of his sickening ‘work’ but for nine years he was living with my mummied daughter in his bedroom. I had her for ten years, he had her for nine.” Moskvin’s mother Elvira, then , told police after he was arrested: We saw these dolls but we did not suspect there were dead bodies inside. We thought it was his hobby to make such big dolls and did not see anything wrong with it.”

title: thai caveman beds dozens attractive
story: NewsThai Caveman beds dozens of attractive female backpackers on island and boasts of exploitsChatupoom Losiri, , has shared images of women sleeping naked in his cave in the Full Moon Party island of Koh PhanganShareCommentsByDave Burke:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video meet-the-cave-man-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA self-proclaimed caveman has boasted online about his years spent bedding dozens of young attractive backpackers he seduced on a Thai island.Lothario Chatupoom Losiri posted pictures of several young woman sleeping naked on his bed on Facebook , claiming they had spent the night together.The -year-old also claimed to have bedded a young Russian woman he met outside a grocery store. But furious locals have voiced their fury at his antics, calling for him to be evicted and prompting police to search his home in the Full Moon Party island of Koh Phangan. Despite claims that he lacked decency after his online bragging, no evidence of any wrongdoing was uncovered in the search. Chatupoom calls himself the Thai Caveman - a persona he uses to pick up women.  After posting a picture of a group naked women sleeping, he wrote that he was very tired from the previous evening but still woke up to drink coffee and meditate while they slept. The cavemans antics sparked outrage from locals who accused him of showing a lack of decency after dozens more images emerged of women he had taken back to his cave. Police arrived at the cave, a former tin mine, yesterday and searched for anything suspicious but found nothing. They admitted that Chatupoom had not broken the law but said they would monitor the situation.  Koh Phangan Sherf Kairik Kraisong said: Officials on Koh Phangan have investigated the situation and performed a background check on the person, who was originally domiciled in Bangkok. He graduated with a degree from Silpakorn University. Koh Phangan district has made an inquiry to the landowner whether he will continue to let Mr Chatupoom live in the area or ask him to leave. Now there are no complaints. If there is a complaint, the officers can take legal action. This situation is precarious and risky, so I sent the staff to check and talk with Mr Chatupoom. Speaking to reporters, Chatupoom denied that he had done anything wrong and said that all of the women who visited his cave were there of their own choice.  He said: I came to Koh Phangan to play music but shortly after the band broke up. Now I earn a living by painting art and selling it to tourists. The women who sleep here, there is no compulsion in any way. None of the women are forced to do anything, and sometimes we dont have sex. Sometimes we just hug until morning. They are all happy and Im happy, too.

title: dundee people green pupils go down to the woods
story: Youngsters from Ardler and St Fergus Primary schools have been busy doing their bit for the environment.The primary six and seven pupils took part in a litter pick in Ardler Woods.Organised by Nicky MacCrimmon from the Strathmartine Regeneration team, the event was the second that the group has done.The pick was arranged with the city council’s neighbourhood services team, which was also represented.Nicky said: “We are trying to get the local community and local primary schools working together.”The pupils carried out a previous litter pick in June just before the summer holidays when they collected  bags of rubbish.The youngsters were treated to refreshments after their activities at the Ardler Complex.Strathmartine Regeneration is one of the community-led organisations supported by the Community Regeneration Section. The aim is to put local communities at the heart of urban regeneration in Dundee by bringing together residents living in more deprived parts of the city.It has been a signicant success and has six forums, each having up to  elected members.

title: dundee united fans to have chance to meet league winning stars
story: Dundee United fans will have the chance to meet heroes from the  league-winning at a special night being held in the city.Whitehall Theatre will host ‘An Evening With The Tangerine Terrors’ on Saturday November  to celebrate the th anniversary of their achievement.Former players including John Holt, Maurice Malpas, Paul Hegarty, Hamish McAlpine, Eamonn Bannon, John Reilly, Davie Dodds and Paul Sturrock will be there on the night.The former teammates will be brought back together for a night of stories and memories from from the unforgettable season # which climaxed by clinching the league title at Dens Park in a - win over Dundee.The show will have an added bit of interest as it will be hosted by Keith Haggart who is the grandson of George Fox # the former long-serving club director.Tickets can be secured on Friday via dundeebox

title: embarrassed freddy frans confident dundee united can recover
story: Dundee United defender Freddy Frans admits he felt embarrassed to have led the side during their - home defeat at the hands of Ross County which, ultimately, spelled the end for Csaba Laszlo.Frans captained the side on the day as Csaba was relieved of his duties as manager in the wake of the Tannadice hammering.His No  Laurie Ellis has taken interim charge and will likely be in the dugout as United travel to Somerset Park to face league leaders Ayr United on Saturday.And, although he is still hurting after the County calamity, Belgian centre-back Frans believes they can bounce back straight away.“People should look at themselves, we don’t need to talk about somebody , we don’t need to talk about the manager or other players,” he said.“We need to look at our own performances and I feel embarrassed.“Especially in an important game like this against one of our title rivals. I can’t remember getting beaten like this.“At half-time there was a lot of emotion, we were trying to get things straight and after the game we’re angry but what can you say  We need to look at ourselves.“It’s easy to look at others and pass the blame on but there is no use in doing that.“We need to stick together.“You always have to be confident, it’s stupid as a football player to think you can’t turn it around. You have to stay positive.“Even though it’s hard to take we have to take it on the chin and go again this weekend.”The -year-old was at a loss to explain what went wrong on Saturday as a Billy Mckay hat-trick and goals from Sean Kelly and Joshua Mullin did the damage for a United side that could only muster one of their own through Pavol Safranko on  minutes.What Frans did accept though, was they need to improvethey want to get the better of the likes of Ross County and others now above them in the race for the Championship title.The Terrors lie in fourth, five points behind leaders Ayr and Frans feels they can learn a thing or two from their promotion rivals.“Sometimes it’s hard to explain in football, you get so much confidence and then this happens. It comes from nowhere,” he added.“I think we started really well. We had a great chance at the beginning and, obviously, we miss it. We concede a stupid goal on a set-piece where we need to be smarter.“We get back into the game with a great goal and, in that moment, I thought we were OK but again we concede a stupid goal again with a cross from the side.“Even then at - it’s bad but I thought ‘look we’ve got  minutes to turn it round’ and then we concede quite early.“The red card for Stewart Murdoch finished it. It’s easy to blame it on mentality but with the goals we conceded it’s about quality as well.“It’s about being smart. That’s what theydid better on Saturday, they were more dirty, more street-wise and we’re too nice.“I can’t blame boys, especially during the week in training, for effort because we train really hard butyou see the game on Saturday it’s logical for the first thing people question to be mentality.“You can run as much as you want butyou don’t do the basics and take a hold of the ball,you don’t pick up your man, simple things like that you’ll lose the game.”Frans apologised to fans, saying: “There’s not much we can say to the supporters, just sorry. I know it’s cheap to say but there is no excuse. We’re just sorry.”

title: give laurie ellis the managers job permanently says dundee united legend john holt
story: Tangerine legend John Holt believes the Dundee United board do not have to leave Tannadice to find the perfect successor to Csaba Laszlo.The man who won the Premier League and two League Cups with United believes caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is the man to take over on a permanent basis.John remains a regular at home matches through his work in the Tannadice hospitality lounges and was sad to see Csaba sacked but believes after a dficult start to the season that the - weekend loss to Ross County made his departure inevitable.“You never like to see a manager sacked and I feel sorry for Csaba, I really do, but it’s been clear for a while now things haven’t been working.“Saturday was another bad home defeat and, for any manager,the team isn’t performing in front of their own fans it’s a big problem.“After the fourth goal I’d say between , and , fans just got up and left. You can’t have that. I know United are not where they want to be right now but even so you can’t have that kind of defeat at a club this size.”“Holtie” was pleased to see Ellis put in interim charge after the manager was sacked on Sunday but feels the way forward was a permanent appointment there and then.“I’ve spoken to Laurie a few times now and he comes across as someone who knows what he’s talking about and how to get the best out of players.“That’s what United need right now because they’ve a decent squad, it’s just that Csaba wasn’t getting the best out of them.“Laurie’s still young and it would be his first job as a manager, but with an experienced No  I think he’d be a success.“He’s got a steely edge to him but he gets along with people. He’d be good with you boys in the press and unlike in my day that’s important for a manager.”If Ellis doesn’t get the nod, the former favourite knows who he’d like to see the club turn to but accepts his second choice may not be heading back to Scotland any time soon.“Billy McKinlay is someone who’d do a great job. ‘Badger’ is a respected coach and he’s someone who knows his stuff.“I think the problem with him would be the level he’s been operating at down in England and where.”

title: jim mcinally backs former dundee united teammate to take over as manager
story: Jim McInally believes a former team mate would be the best choice as Dundee United’s new manager.The Tangerines are searching for a replacement for Csaba Lazlo.But Tannadice legend McInally would plump for Billy McKinlay, who made  appearances for United and has worked as a coach with Roy Hodgson at Fulham and David Moyes at Real Sociedad, Sunderland and West Ham.McInally, now Peterhead boss, told the Evening Express: “There are problems in boardrooms with chairman and directors who don’t look at the bigger picture enough.“Billy McKinlay had one failed spell as a manager in Norway.“But ultimately he’s worked at the highest level with Real Sociedad, Fulham under Roy Hodgson and last season at West Ham, and David Moyes thinks the world of him.#What I know about Billy is that he’s a really good organiser of a team and from what I understand that’s what United need.“It’s not just because he’s an old team-mate but he’s somebody that’s dferent and I would like to see the people making the decision look at the bigger picture.”McInally, who played  times for United, is desperate to see his old clubto the Premiership.He added: “Their current plight has been down to lack of leadership at the top.#

title: man taken to ninewells after standoff with cops in dundee street overnight
story: A man has been taken to Ninewells after an hour-long standoff with police on a Dundee street overnight. vw, px"  As many as five police vehicles rushed to Harlow Place shortly before am.Officers with riot shields were spotted by shocked residents.A police statement said: #Officers engaged with a distressed male there and he was traced safe and well. As a precaution he was taken to Ninewells Hospital, Dundee.Inspector Martin Pattie said “Given the time of incident, there was minimal disruption to residents and the general public.#I would like reassure the community that at no stage was there any danger to members of the public”.See today#s Tele for more on this story.

title: neil mccann backs his dundee players to handle the heat
story: Dundee will have to face a dferent kind of pressure this weekend against Kilmarnock but manager Neil McCann is backing his players to handle it once again.The Dark Blues boss was full of praise for the way his defence dealt with Hamilton’s direct approach in the second half of their - victory.Accies brought on strikers Rakish Bingham and on-loan Mason Bloomfield as they bombarded the Dundee defensive line.However, with the help of the crossbar a couple of times, Dundee held out and lted some of the heat that’s been on the manager and his team after the six straight defeats that began their season.With Killie’s attacking line of Greg Stewart, Eamonn Brophy, Jordan Jones, Chris Burke and Kris Boyd it’ll be a dferent sort of pressure the Dark Blues will have to be ready to deal with.Neil, though, expects the edginess in their defending as they homed in on their first win to be gone come Saturday.He said: “The next game will be a tough one against Kilmarnock but we enjoyed last weekend because it had been a long time coming.“Against Hamilton, I knew they would go direct, they brought Bingham on and did go more direct.“You have to deal with that – there is only so much you can do as a manager, tactically, and the players have to deal with it.“You have to be able to deal with the threat of them going direct.“There was a wee bit of edge still in their game because I’ve been saying for weeks I’d love to see them go in front and see what it did to their game.“I always knew they would still be playing with pressure but they dealt with that.“They had to deal with long balls, there were a couple of balls flashed across the goal but I thought we were well worth our three points last Saturday.”Meanwhile, a Dundee reserve side including first-teamers Jack Hamilton, Darren O’Dea, Jesse Curran and Jean Mendy were thrashed - by Dunfermline at Kelty Hearts’ New Central Park.It was Jimmy Boyle’s men’s first defeat in the Reserve League with goals from Lewis McCann, two from former Dundee United man Robbie Muirhead and second-half penalties from Tom Beadling and Myles Hippolyte counting for the Pars.The match did see a first outing for new Dee signing Grant Nelson.The -year-old from Rangers signed up with Boyle’s reserve side before the contest.

title: no looking back now for dundee after win nabi
story: There’s no looking back now for Dundee after they picked up their first victory of the season at the weekend, according to attacker Adil Nabi.The - success at the Hope CBD Stadium in Hamilton brought a welcome end to their run of seven-straight league defeats which stretched back all the way to last season.And, now they have got up and running finally, Nabi says it’s onwards and upwards for his new side.And he’s targeting a second result on the bounce when Kilmarnock come to Dens this coming Saturday.He said: “We’re not looking back – it’s all about looking forward now as a team and it’s about kicking on.“Bring on Saturday back at home.“We didn’t really look at the table but we knew the situation, you can’t hide away from that but as a team we have shown what we are like and we’re going to keep going and going.“On our day we can beat anyone, we’re not scared of anyone.“When we play like we played at Hamilton, showing both sides of the game, we can beat anyone.”The former West Brom and Peterborough forward, who signed for the Dark Blues in the summer, admits they had a bit of luck on their side against Accies.However, he insists that was deserved after a performance that showed two sides to Dundee’s current side.“It was overdue,” he added.“We rode our luck and got some luck back on Saturday – they hit the bar twice but we showed we can play our football and we can fight as well.“We showed that in abundance on Saturday.“Everyone is over the moon, the gaffer, the boys, absolutely buzzing and cant wait for the next game.“If you’re going to win sometimes you have to ride the storm and we rode it quite well.“There was no doubting they would come at us and put us under the cosh. We were troubled a few times but that was it, really.“We played as a team and that’s what we are about, to be honest.“We can play football but we know how to change it up sometimes, we can play long or play short and we showed that on Saturday.”Nabi has had to be patient in his short Dundee career so far after impressing during the club’s pre-season training trip to Portugal and earning a six-month deal.Saturday was just his fth start for the club and he says he’s starting to feel he’s up to speed.And he has promised to repay a lot of online support from Dundee fans by beginning to hit the net.Nabi had the chance to open his account against Hamilton but sent a good opportunity over the bar.He added: “I said to the gaffer that after my third, fourth start I’d be firing.“I’m slowly showing that, getting chances and looking lively.“I know the fans are happy with me – I read on the internet all the time that they are buzzing!“Hopefully, now I can start getting myself on the scoresheet and carry on.“I should have put that one away definitely but that’s going to come, I know that for sure.“My goals will come.”And with the club finally heading in the right direction, Nabi expects to have more opportunities to score as the team’s fortunes improve.“The win changes the mindset for us. As a team, when we were losing, we didn’t really let that get to us.“I know we’ve been under pressure having not won but as a team we’ve been positive.“We always knew we wanted to get that goal first and we showed what we can do when we get in front. There’s no better feeling than coming away with the three points and long may it continue.“Our season starts now and whatever happened before is past and we need to kick on.”

title: paul quinn claims paul sturrocks role undermined csaba laszlo at dundee united
story: Former Dundee United defender Paul Quinn believes there have to be major changes at the clubthey are to progress.A policy was introduced in the summer to ensure new signings live within a -mile radius of the city but Quinn felt that was papering over the cracks.He said: “Dundee United fans have proved themselves to be good, loyal supporters over the years. They want the best for their club but when you are in Dundee getting moaned at from fans, I guess in restaurants etc, that’s not helpful to the players.“What they should try and change is Tannadice.“When you go in the door it needs modernised.“I love all their history. There are players there up on the wall who I couldn’t even begin to lace their boots. Even within the tunnel area, though, could there not be something changed to reflect the modern era “Something needs to change in the mental side of things to move Dundee United forward.”Quinn was surprised to see club legend Paul Sturrockto Tannadice in March as an adviser to Csaba Laszlo. He said: “Our manager is our leader – that’s the golden rule in football.“You give the gaffer everything but then somebody  comes in all of a sudden and immediately you think: ‘What’s going on here ’“Players talk as football is a small world. They think: ‘The manager likes me but do I now need to keep this new guy happy as well ’“I felt for Csaba then. There’s no way you can dispute what Luggy did as a player for United but that was back in the day.“It looked from the outside as though there was undermining going on – that’s just a fact.”

title: poll results arabs come out in favour of one man to take on dundee united managers job
story: Dundee United fans have given a clear indication that they want a new face to take charge at the club, an exclusive Tele poll has revealed.The Tangerines are on the hunt for a new manager after the departure of Csaba Laszo on Sunday.A number of names have been linked with the position, including long-term assistant Laurie Ellis.However, Arabs who took part in our online poll have come out in favour of former Hearts gaffer Robbie Neilson.The -year-old, whose last spell as a manager was at MK Dons, received % of the voteafter , people took part in the poll.Current interim boss Laurie Ellis came second with % of fans backing him to take the hotseat on a permanent basis.Both Neilson and Ellis are currently the bookies# joint favourites to take on the role permanently.St Johnstone gaffer Tommy Wright was third on the fans# wish list at % # however, in reality the chances of the Northern Irishman coming to manage at Tannadice are slim to none.The poll results in full :Robbie Neilson Laurie Ellis       Tommy Wright Jim McIntyre    Terry Butcher   Billy McKinlay John Hughes     Dick Campbell  Paul Sturrock    Billy Dodds      Ian McCall       Steven Pressley John Robertson Other                 Of the respondents,  people selected the #other# category and suggested other names including former United man Barry Robson, legendary forward Duncan Ferguson, Maurice Malpas and Ian Cathro.Supporter Dave Stewart commented on the poll suggesting Danny Lennon takes charge.He wrote: #Laurie Ellis is guilty by association with the last two failures.#One Tommy Wright voter commented: #We need an experienced manager # no more ex players or inexperienced men.#Robbie Neilson supporters felt he had a decent track record in the SPFL to take the job.One wrote: #It has to be someone that has been in top flight football before. Going with an unknown is completely unacceptable.#Another said: #Robbie Neilson for me. He did a good job with Hearts, he can work on a small budget and knows the Championship well.#While one Arab wrote: #Laurie deserves an opportunity to be in charge of training and discoverhe can motivate players to achieve results in next few matches.#It would be a huge gamble but there are also massive risks appointing some unemployed ex United players. Tough decisions for Mike Martin.#

title: relieved gaffer neil hopes hamilton win is turning point for dundee
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann says he hopes his side have turned the corner on their season after being “well worth the three points” at Hamilton.The Dark Blues earned their first Premiership victory of the season with a - success at the Hope CBD Stadium with goals at the end of each half from defender Andy Boyle and midfielder Kharl Madianga.Heading into the contest, the Dens men had no points to their name after six matches but have cut the gap to the teams above them with St Mirren and Motherwell now just a point ahead in th and th position respectively.Dundee gaffer Neil was delighted to finally get off the mark and is hoping it’s just a belated start to the season for his side.He said: “I hope this is the turning point. I just felt we needed to get the first win and I believe in them to go on now.“We enjoyed the weekend because it had been a long time coming.“It’s a relief to get the three points, I’m not going to lie but I’m really pleased for the guys because I’ve been talking for weeks about the belief I still have in them that they could get a result.“I thought we were well worth the three points.“I thought we absolutely dominated the first half, we didn’t change how we played – there’s no use in me saying I have belief in them and then changing how we play.“I thought it was the right way to go on Saturday and we dominated the ball, created chances and it was a great header from Boyle.”On more than one occasion this season Dundee have had the better of the overall play but were unable to take advantage by grabbing the lead.This time, though, with Preston loanee Boyle’s th minute header they did just that and, after seeing Accies pass up a number of chances, sealed victory in stoppage time as Madianga smashed the ball beyond Gary Woods to send the fans and the bench delirious.Neil added: “It was sheer joy. Football is about winning games and when you’re down sometimes you don’t get a lot of luck but we got a bit of luck on Saturday.“I’ve been hammering to them about getting into the lead but we’ve been conceding goals quickly and that belief that you can win games clearly reduces.“I just said to them that our gameplan is to get into the lead, not to just sit back and try to recover from - down.“However, only they can make that happen. Hamilton will have said, ‘get a goal against them and they’re dead’ but the players were well fired up on Saturday, I didn’t have to do anything.“When the goal goes in from Boyle, great delivery from Calvin Miller, you know you have something tangible to hang on to.“I’m so pleased, I don’t want to go overboard because it is only three points but it is a big three points for the club.”

title: Fee introduction was a factor in recyling rate dip but just a blip insists Highland Council
story: THE controversial introduction of the fee for emptying brown bins was a factor in the arearsquos dip in recycling rates last year.But Highland Council chiefs say it was just a blip.While the level of household waste recycled nationally exceeded the amount sent to landfill for the first time, the tonnage slipped in Highland.The regionrsquos  recycling feat of . per cent dropped last year to . per cent ndash and last year a pound charge was brought in for emptying garden waste bins. This fee was increased to pound this year.The councilrsquos vice convener Allan Henderson, who also is also chairman of the environment committee, said: ldquoWhile wersquore getting better at recycling, the change to charging for brown bins has meant some garden waste being channelled into municipal waste.ldquoI believe our proposal to build a lsquomaterial recovery facilityrsquo and roll out extra brown bin coverage will reverse this slight dip.The latest figures from the Scottish Environment Protection Agencyshow that recycling rates improved at  of Scotlandrsquos  local authorities.It estimates that . per cent of waste generated in Scotland was recycled, which was an annual increase of . per cent.Scotlandrsquos environment secretary Roseanna Cunningham welcomed the figures but said more progress was needed, particularly in the cities.The biggest increases in recycling rates were in West Lothian, East Renfrewshire, Dumfries and Galloway, South Ayrshire and Aberdeen City.Ms Cunningham said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has big plans for tackling waste plastics, in particular by introducing a depositscheme, to further incentivise people to recycle.ldquoWersquove also introduced a household recycling charter for local authorities to sign up to, which is making the approach to recycling less confusing for households and creating a more consistent and efficient system for authorities.The Sepa figures show the amount of household waste generated in Scotland was . million tonnes in  ndash a decrease of , tonnes from .Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Gaelic centre plan has backing of Inverness public
story: A SURVEY has shown that there is signicant public support for a new Gaelic cultural centre in Inverness.The research, which was carried out by the Alba Heritage Trust with the aim of establishing the level of interest in a project celebrating Gaelic heritage, was met with ldquooverwhelming backing from members of the public.Alba Heritage Trust director Alastair Forbes says the reaction has from businesses and iniduals across the board has been signicant.ldquoWe are delighted to have had so many responses to the survey, he said.ldquoThe reaction from the public and private sectors and from members of the community for the establishment of a Gaelic cultural centre has been extremely positive which has given us great confidence in moving forward with the project.Dr Blackrsquos Memorial Hall in the city centre has already been earmarked as a potential venue for the initiative ndash backed by an architectural survey.Plans for potential facilities in the centre include a Gaelic cafeacute, a retail space selling Gaelic-themed products, and language classes as well as a cultural exhibition.It would also host ceilidhs, shows and performances, as well as talks and lectures on the subject of Gaelic culture.Alba Heritage Trust director Emily Macdonald said: ldquoA cultural centre of this type would be of great benefit to the city of Inverness and the wider Highland area.ldquoIt would provide a focal point for anyone with an interest in Gaelic language and culture.ldquoThe potential impacts include promoting Gaelic language and culture, increasing Gaelic usage, encouraging community interaction, attracting further cultural events to the city, creating jobs and enhancing Invernessrsquos offering as a centre for tourism.Friday  Oct  : AM

story: A gay pride march through the centre of Inverness has been given the go-ahead.Proud Ness, which will take place on October , has been at the centre of a bitter row after Donald Morrison, a home mission worker with the Free Church of Scotland , submitted a petition to Highland Council signed by  people opposing the event on "biblical, religious and moral grounds".In response, thousands of supporters signed counter petitions, saying gay pride was celebrated all over the world and the people of Inverness wanted to be on the right side of history.The council confirmed this morning the march can go ahead."We have notied the organisers that Highland Council and Police Scotland have no objections to the march being held as per the details in their notice of intention," the spokeswoman said.Previously, the spokeswoman said the petitions from both sides would not have a bearing on the decision process as the raised matters of concern were not sufficient reason to refuse the parade.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Highland Council shouldnt have to shoulder cost of Universal Credit introduction argues MP
story: Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry is calling on the UK government to meet the additional burden and is also seeking an urgent meeting with Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey.It follows a similar demand from council leader Margaret Davidson who says the costs should not be met by Highland council tax and rent payers.Inverness was first chosen in  as the only place in Scotland to trial the much-criticised welfare reform which was implemented in the city two years ago and in the rest of the Highlands last year.Despite tales from claimants facing a tide of debt and dficulties ndash many of which were highlighted in the Inverness Courier ndash it is also being rolled out across the UK.But Mr Hendry described the move as ldquoshambolic and said people in the Highlands were having to subsidise the government for its failed project.ldquoDay in, day out, Highland Council staff have to deal with a system littered with inefficiencies and a host of process failures ndash costing not only more time for officers but lots more money from the councilrsquos budget, he said. ldquoIn addition to meeting administration costs, Highland Council is also having to burden the cost of rent arrears which have shot through the roof because of theof time people and landlords have to wait for payments. It simply cannot go on.According to figures obtained by Mr Hendry, the council spent pound, between - to administer universal credit but only received pound, from the government, leaving a gap of pound,.The figures also showed more than half the councilrsquos pound. million in rent arrears was directly attributable to the new system.Mr Hendry warned with nearly , people in the Highlands still to be transferred to universal credit the bill would continue to rise.Councillor Davidson also wrote to Ms McVey in August seeking full reimbursement of the costs but is still awaiting a reply.ldquoThe council continues to support claimants who are impacted by universal credit as a result of flaws in the system, Cllr Davidson said.But the councilrsquos Conservative leader Andrew Jarvie said lessons had been learned and issues ironed out.ldquoIt is easy to look at headline figures and see the situation gets blown out of all proportion, he said. ldquoPrior to universal credit, housing rent arrears were about pound million.A spokesman for the Department of Work and Pensions said support was provided for claimants as they moved to universal credit while a flexible payment system had been introduced in Scotland.ldquoRent arrears are complicated and they cannot be attributed to a single cause, he said. ldquoOur research shows that many people join universal credit with pre-existing arrears but the proportion of people with arrears falls by a third after four months on universal credit.-Drew Hendry will hold a welfare surgery on Friday for anyone struggling with benefit or welfare issues as part of the Poverty Alliancersquos Challenge Poverty Week.It will take place between noon and pm at Merkinch Community Centre.Other organisations taking part include Highland Council, Citizens Advice Bureau, Inverness Cathedral, Advocacy Highland, Employability Skills and Welfare Project, and MFR Cash for Kids.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Inverness streets past preserved by key heritage trail
story: The new digital heritage trail, a key part of the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, spent the past two-and-a-half years engaging with the community around Academy Street.During that time some  heritage lsquoengagement eventsrsquo were held and people were invited to share their stories.In the end more than  came forward, representing people such as A. I. Welders Social Group, the Second Inverness Girls Brigade and the congregation and community of the East Church.Their input has brought to light a wealth of high quality content for the website, as well as opening up the rich iety of materials available in the cityrsquos museum, library and archive collections.And this new digital heritage trail was tested by stakeholders at Inverness Museum and Art Gallerylast week.Their feedback will help the developers, AOC Archaeology, refine and shape the website before it is launched on October .The site has been designed to continually evolve as more content is generated.A range of the results from the public engagement are currently on display at IMAG, including stunning detailed line drawings of Academy Street in  by Gordon Lynn.The Townscape Heritage Partnership chairman, Councillor Richard Laird, said: ldquoI am delighted to try out the website and to see how it showcases the rich iety of material that members of the public have so generously brought forward to save for generations of residents and visitors to our city.The project was run in partnership with High Le Highland and AOC Archaeology.Ian Murray, chief executive of High Le Highland, added: ldquoIt has been fascinating to hear the stories of Academy Street as told by over  iniduals who have generously contributed to the project.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Models needed for Inverness charity event
story: The event, to be held at Inverness Town House, is being organised by the Archie Foundation.It is looking for  males and  females aged over  and of all shapes and sizes with any connection to Raigmorersquos childrenrsquos unit or the foundation.They could include former patients and their families, or staff.The new childrenrsquos unit opened in  following a pound million appeal launched by the foundation in conjunction with The Inverness Courier.The foundation is now hoping to raise pound, for the Fresh Air project which will include fun features and topiary animals such as a ft Nessie.The fashion show will be held on Friday November  from pm to pm. title: Port cruises to best ever year
story: THE Port of Cromarty Firth recorded its best ever year in , with almost pound million in turnover, it has reported.Its annual review reports a turnover of pound. million ndash pound million higher than its previous turnover record in .A ersication from its core business of oil and gas to renewables, decommissioning and cruise and a higher number of vessels than expected resulted in the improvement. Many of the visitors have been taken by coach to hot spots such as Inverness and Loch Ness.The strong results will allow the port at Invergordon to continue to invest in major developments, such as the new quayside and laydown space, which is in the planning stages for construction through Chief executive Bob Buskie said: ldquoAt the start of , with low oil and gas prices, we knew the port had to adapt to sustain our growth and help keep local people in work.ldquoFirstly, supporting our core customers in oil and gas was a key concern.ldquoAfter the necessary consultation, we introduced a new pricing for statutory dues in January , which meant an average five per cent reduction in fees for most clients, supporting them through the downturn.ldquoSecondly, the port had to look to the future and see what we could do to help sustain jobs and growth.The cruise-liner market was a success last year, with the port being named as the busiest in Scotland. It welcomed  ships and more than , passengers mdash a  per cent increase on . The direct spend from passengers is put at pound million.The port has outlined plans to build a new multi-use berth development to provide modern facilities and to accommodate the larger cruise ships.The port also ran two workshops, in conjunction with the cruise companies and Highlands and Islands Enterprise, to help local businesses understand and work with this lucrative sector. A cruise stakeholder group was also established to help improve logistics and communication.Port board chairman Douglas Russell said hard work by its staff saw produced the record-breaking year.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Pressure on Highland Council to stub out unethical investments
story: HIGHLAND Council could review its stake-holding in tobacco, alcohol and weapons companies.Opposition to such selections was spelled out by Ross-shire councillor Angela MacLean amid long running anger about the ethics of the local authority investing millions of pounds in such industries while also claiming to promote ldquohealthy lestyles through council policies.Over the past  years, a small band of councillors has registered opposition to widely perceived ldquounethical investments but to no effect.Independent fund managers are employed to get the maximum . Recent figures showed the fund increased in value in - by pound. million. As of last weekend, it was valued at pound,,,..Addressing colleagues on the audit and scrutiny committee, Cllr MacLean called for a review of investment strategy. She acknowledged the need to secure the best .But she added: ldquoSome people are not happy with some of the investments and feel that perhapsitrsquos invested in tobacco or arms or things like that, itrsquos not ethically responsible.She asked whether fund trustees had any say in the choice of investments.The councilrsquos investments change on a daily basis.Recent examples of contentious choices include British American Tobacco , liqueurs firm Pernod Ricard , pubs chain Mitchells and Butlers , Japan Tobaccoand Chinarsquos second largest brewery, Tsingtao .The councilrsquos finance director Derek Yule explained that an investments sub-committee reports to a pension board which sets the strategy.ldquoIt is very dficult when some of the investment strategy seeks to invest in shares in companies not just in the UK but worldwide, he said.ldquoWhilst I totally understand some of the ethical debate, it is very dficult to draw a line sometimes.ldquoYou might take a viewhellip would you invest in banks, for example  They might not be the best investment, anyway. But I use that as an example because banks will fund these companies.ldquoItrsquos a dficult balancing act but itrsquos certainly within your rightsyou wished the pension board to look at the investment strategy.ldquoFund managers are given guidelines to work to, so that would be quite legitimate for the council to do through the pension board.According to current policy, the fund ldquorecognises that social, environmental and ethical considerations are among factors investment managers will take into account, where relevant, when selecting investments for purchase, retention or sale.However, it stresses that ldquothe overriding consideration for pension committee members is their fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and scheme members.The Scheme Advisory Board, established up by the Scottish Government to regulate such public sector pension funds, recently obtained advice from legal counsel on the duty of pensions committees.The guidance concluded that: ldquoPensions committees in Scotland owe a fiduciary duty to the scheme employers and the scheme members in general and specically in relation to investment matters.ldquoThose duties should be exercised in the best interests of the beneficiaries and in relation to investment decisions, should aim to achieve the best financial position for the fund, balancing risk andin the usual way.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Recovery cafe celebrates official launch in Inverness
story: Our Place ndash or Ar n-Aite in Gaelic ndash will make its money serving cappuccinos and macchiatos to the general public, pouring the proceeds back into the enterprise.Staff at the Church Street hub will be drawn from a pool of ex-prisoners who agree to work for free infor on-the-job training.And pensioners and other do-gooders will put their green fingers to good use growing as much free fruit and vegetables as the cafeacute needs to feed its hungry customers.But in a slight hiccup managers at the Signpost charity which is spearheading Our Place are having to meet with some traders who voiced concern crime could rocketa high concentration of ex-offenders are put under one roof.James Docherty from Scotlandrsquos Crime Reduction Unit which is backing the cafeacute said the tradersrsquo concerns were ldquoa symptom of social exclusion.ldquoSocially excluding people is more likely to cause a rise in crime, he said.ldquoWe run a similar project in Glasgow called Street and Arrow. Itrsquos police-led but facilitated by people from an offendersrsquo background and itrsquos a blinding success.And speaking at the opening launch Inverness and Nairn MP Drew Hendry said: ldquoPart of the plan for the Inverness Cafeacute on Church Street is to use vegetables locally-grown by those who use the cafe and those who work in it, and its customers.ldquoThis is named lsquoGrow your own communityrsquo ndash how apt. What is really being planted here though is the new generation, the seeds of the next crop of people who understand inclusion, equality, community and respect.Alan Fowler, community programmes manager for Signpost said: ldquoWe want to create an environment where therersquos no them and us.It has secured pound, from Highland Council and pound, from The Robertson Trust.Friday  Oct  : AM

title: Time to tap into healthier lifestyle
story: Scottish Government ViewpointSCOTTISH Water has announced plans to roll out tap water refill points around Scotland over the next two years.Councils are being consulted to identy the best locations with the aim of having the first  Top Up Taps installed by the end of next March.The move follows the launch earlier this year of the Your Water, Your Le campaign in which the utility giant called for customers to drink tap water at home, at work and on the move as a way of reducing waste, saving themselves money and staying hydrated.Edinburgh will be the first location for a Top Up Tap with the installation going in by the end of this month outside the front of the Scottish Parliament.Other sites being considered for the initial roll-out include Inverness and Fort William.The units will be fitted with technology that will enable the company to digitally track water usage at each Top Up point.The resulting data will be used to calculate cost and plastic savings, along with the volume of water being consumed.Douglas Millican, Scottish Water chief executive, said: "Our research shows that people feel very positively towards the quality of Scotlands tap water ndash now these state-of-the-art taps can provide access to enable water drinkers to enjoy it while on the go by carrying and using refillable bottles."A national drive to encourage people to stay hydrated by drinking water from the tap in refillable bottles was set out in the Scottish Governments Programme for Government -. Environment Secretary Roseanna Cunningham said she is delighted to see it being implemented so swtly.She said: "By encouraging people to top up from the tap using refillable bottles, we will help cut down on our use of plastics and promote the benefits of hydration building on Scottish Waters Your Water, Your Le campaign."I now look forward to refilling my bottle at the Top Up Tap outside the parliament in the coming months."The Your Water, Your Le campaign aims to make tap the first choice for water drinkers wherever they are, and encourages businesses to make it readily available for staff and customers.Water samples will be tested every two minutes, on average, to ensure that quality is maintained.Licensed premises are legally bound to serve tap water on request, yet research shows Scots are uncomfortable asking, something this campaign hopes to change. Customer research by Scottish Water revealed tap is the water of choice for almost two thirds of people in Scotland , and currently over a thirdcarry reusable bottles always or often when out and about. But less than a thirdsaid theyd be happy to go into a cafeacute and ask for their bottle to be filled.On average a litre bottle of water costs about p, so topping up daily from the tap, could save pound. a day, nearly pound a year.The Top Up Taps are made from marine-grade steel and are connected to the mains water supply.* For further information visit www.yourwateryourleFriday  Oct  : AM

title: conservation group claims vandals are sabotaging wildcat work
story: Vandals are sabotaging vital research into an endangered animal in a forest, a conservation group has claimed.Scottish Wildcat Actionhas a team supported by almost  volunteers working to protect the endangered creatures in Clashindarroch Forest near Huntly.The group uses cameras and traps to record wildcat numbers and health, and monitor the prevalence of voles, which wildcats eat.Helpers were rocked in March when they discovered two camera traps had been stolen.At the time, SWA leaders believed the motive was theft – but traps were tampered with again some time around September  and now Forest Enterprise Scotland , which manages the woodland on behalf of the Scottish Government, believes someone is sabotaging the research.A FES spokesman said: “A number of catch-and-release traps were opened, emptied and discarded.“We have called in police to help trace a vandal who is attempting to sabotage efforts to conserve Scottish wildcats.”FES species ecologist Kenny Kortland said: “This sabotage is extremely frustrating as it jeopardises vital research.“Whoever did this obviously has no interest in saving wildcats – these traps were well hidden so not discovered by accident and it would seem like a deliberate act of sabotage. Studies into wildcats and their prey are only validthey are scientically rigorous, and this kind of interference decreases the risk of that happening. Ultimately, it means we don’t know as much about these endangered animals as we could.”He added: “Vandalism is an attempt to disrupt our efforts, as part of Scottish Wildcat Action, to help conserve Scotland’s endangered and dwindling wildcat population. We would urge anyone with any information about this crime to contact the police.”Police ask anyone with information to call  quoting reference  of September .

title: how joining the british army opened up my world to travel and education
story: As recruitment for new soldiers begins in the north-east, Lance Corporal McWalters, tells why serving with the British Army helped to turn his le around.Sitting in a classroom day after day, it’s hard to imagine carving out a career in the world of work.And that was especially the case for Aberdeen-born McWalters, who admits he didn’t always get along with his teachers and always tried to be the funny lad.Like many people across the country, McWalter didn’t always know what he wanted to do with his le – jumping around from job to job as a teenager and getting in spots of bother, he soon found a place he could belong. vw, px"  McWalter soon joined the Army and began serving in the Royal Electrical Mechanical Engineers, where he started to forge a successful career and grow as a person.“My job role is basically I can fix vehicles and I can diagnose problems, soa vehicle goes down then the mission is not going to be successful.”“The thing I’ve enjoyed about my job is that I’ve learned a trade that I’ll have for the rest of my le. I’ve got my MVQ level three and I’ve got experience of mechanics”However, McWalter didn’t realise that a career in the Army would also mean traveling the world and playing in international football tournaments.“I’ve always played football at a decent standard. So when I was told that you can play sports in the Army, I thought I’d give it a go.”He added: . “I never expected football to play a big part in the Army. The amount of times I’ve been away playing football in tournaments… I went to Boston and New York on a football tournament. With the regiment I’m at just now, I’ve just came back from Toronto – it’s brilliant!” vw, px"  The Army is now recruiting for new soldiers across the country, and opportunities are available for a wide range of backgrounds.Like Mcwalter, new recruits will have the chance to make a dference and become a better version of themselves.He said: “I’ve grown up from the Army and from training. title: move to get city veterans more accommodation
story: A north-east council is to get advice from a charity on how make it easier for veterans to find housing.The Disabled Persons Housing Servicehas welcomed Aberdeen City Council’s initiative to ensure % of , new council homes are offered to those leaving the armed forces.The charity, based in Aberdeen, offers housing advice, information and advocacy to disabled people, their families and carers.Representatives of the charity had previously met Mark McDonald MSP, who represents the Aberdeen Donside ward, to discuss their concerns with how best to help veterans.Mr McDonald said: “I am pleased that Aberdeen City Council will be working on identying veterans as part of their housing allocations policy.“This will go some way to helping ease the challenges faced by former service personnel who often struggle to get appropriate housing when they leave the forces.“I have dealt with a number of constituency cases in the past where veterans have struggled to obtain housing, and where their needs have not always been appropriately identied, anything that can be done to improve this is to be welcomed.”Aberdeen City Lord Provost Barney Crockett confirmed that DPHS would be consulted when the next housing application is being developed.He said: “There are a lot of organisations doing great work across the country.“We are aware that veterans can face a certain set of problems and the more people involved in making that easier for them the better.”Manager of the DPHS Shirley Finlayson admitted that though the percentage set aside for veterans was small, it was “a start”.She said: “It is a small amount but it is amazing and I feel very encouraged by it.“We have pushed for this because we have applications for support out of the door and many of them need a particular type of help.“We liaise a lot with the housing service but this was a hallelujah moment.“We can help veterans and ex-forces personnel – whether they have a disability or not – but they can often be quite a close-knit community and so we want to make sure they know what help is on offer.”Up to  new council homes will be offered to those leaving the armed forces or to the spouses and dependents of those who have died while serving.The move was unanimously backed by a meeting of all councillors as they tried to agree a refreshed armed forces covenant for the city last month.Councillors also agreed that a donation of £, will be made to the Poppy Scotland Appeal to support its activities, with a focus on the Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire areas.Other commitments within the covenant include providing career advice to those planning to leave the forces and supporting Armed Forces Day.

title: north east friends appear on tv quiz show 5 gold rings1
story: Two north-east best friends who appeared on a prime-time TV show may not have walked away with the £, prize money – but are still smiling.Aileen Merchant, , and Dave Senior, , both from Portlethen, took part in Sunday night’s episode of the hit ITV show  Gold Rings.Hosted by Phillip Schofield, the interactive game sees two teams go head-to-head over five rounds where they answer questions and place a gold ring on the image where they think the answer is.Each side is competing to walk away with up to £,. Sadly, the duo – who were in the lead for the majority of the game – ended up losing out to married couple Louisa and April.Aileen said: “It was such an amazing experience.“Obviously we couldn’t say how we did before the show which was really frustrating so it’s great to be able to talk about it now. The whole way through my friends were saying ‘you must have won’ so that was a little awkward.“Doing the show was a great experience to have – it was all a bit surreal as well.“It was a long day but everyone was so nice and friendly which made it an amazing experience.“We watched the show in McGinty’s with all our friends which was so much fun.“I made lots of jokes on the show about firing Dave since I used to work for him back then but don’t worry – we’re still best friends.”Challenges they faced included pointing out where the vertical line is in the Swedish flag and picking the highest point in the London Eye.Despite the disappointment of not walking away with the prize money, Aileen, an operations director at a property management company, said she was happy to see the other team win.She said: “They had a lovely story about wanting to start a family and use the money for their mortgage whereas I was just going to blow the money on botox so it was nice that they won.“I said to Dave ahead of the show that I just didn’t want us to look like idiots and I think we achieved that.”Dave, a managing director of an IT support firm, said: “We were so close to winning but I’m proud of how we did.“It was fantastic to be involved in the show.“We filmed it quite a long time ago now and I think we forgot just how close it had been. We had so much adrenaline going through us.”Dave added that he has enjoyed seeing everyone’s reaction after it was aired.He said: “We didn’t embarrass ourselves which was definitely our biggest worry.”

title: north east man admits driving while disqualified
story: A man has admitted getting behind the wheel while disqualied.Michael Stephen, , appeared at Aberdeen Sherf Court on Wednesday over the offence on Kingsfield Road, Kintore.He pled guilty to driving while disqualied and also without insurance on Tuesday.Defence agent Liam McAllister said: “He’s more than aware that due to his utter stupidity all sentencing options are open.”He added his client is in full-time employment as a gardener and is the sole provider for his family.Sherf Sukhwinder Gill told Stephen, of Howieslap, Kintore: “Given the nature of the charge to which you’ve pled guilty I’m going to call for reports.”Sherf Gill deferred sentence on Stephen until October  and further disqualied him from driving in the interim period.

title: nursery helps spruce up hospice playroom
story: Nursery pupils helped to bring a splash of colour to an Aberdeen hospice as they opened a new playroom.Children from the Little Acorn Nursery visited Roxburghe House in Aberdeen to officially open its newly-refurbished playroom after helping to raise £, for its transformation. vw, px"  The room, now complete with toys, games and an interactive television screen, is now available for patients of all ages and relatives of older patients.After completing a sponsored walk along the Beach Esplanade, the pupils donated to the room’s revamp to join the efforts of the Friends of Roxburghe House Grampian charity.The revamp also benefited from a donation from the hospice’s SPAR store. vw, px"  Treasurer of the group Peter Clark said: “We identied the play area as being in need of refurbishment two years ago so it has been a long time in the making.“The donations from SPAR and the Little Acorns nursery have helped to transform the room.“Though Roxburghe House is primarily for adults, there are children who stay here and many who visit so this can provide some respite for them.#Roxburghe House’s SPAR also contributed to the appeal by donating £, accrued by the p bag charge.When it came to redesigning the formerly plain room, NHS activities co-ordinator Liz McDonald conducted research.She said: “I’ve been involved in the project from the start and at times it felt like it would never be finished so it is great to see it being used.“I visited playrooms in the Royal Aberdeen Children’s Hospital and CLAN to see what we could try, and we asked ex-service users and their relatives for their opinions.“We made it colourful to attract the little children but we added the ‘pod’ chair for the older children. It has chargers nearby and blocks out the sound around you, so it will be good for when they are having a hard time and just want to get away from it all.Henry McBain, , cut the ceremonial ribbon – with child-friendly scissors – and said: “I like the Lego the best.” vw, px"

title: park eyes up cup hat trick as cove face old rival dee
story: Cove Rangers’ Daniel Park is dreaming of making it a hat-trick of Evening Express Aberdeenshire Cup winners’ medals.The Highland League champions take on Banks o’ Dee on Friday in the famous old competition’s showpiece at Inverurie’s Harlaw Park.Park has won the tournament twice, firstly with Cove in  and then with Formartine United in .Although those victories are happy memories for the winger, the last two years provide painful memories.Two years ago Cove lost on penalties to Buckie Thistle after a - draw, when they had led -, and  months ago were edged out - by Formartine.Park would love to make up for that this year and get his own Shire Cup treble and avoid an unwanted hat-trick of final defeats.He says their previous defeats also given them motivation.Park said: “Most of the guys have won the cup before. I won it first time round at Cove and then again at Formartine.“But we’re not dwelling on the past, it would be good to get this one under the belt this early in the season.“They are happy memories the first time at Cove we beat Buckie and then at Formartine we beat Inverurie.“It’s always good to win cup finals, whoever you are playing for. You want to win every cup you enter and it would be sweet to get something in the trophy cabinet early in the season.“I would love to make it a hat-trick in the cup.“The last couple of years are in our minds. We’ve done well to get to the finals the last two years.“Probably on both occasions we’ve been unlucky not to win then. After losing, it does give us motivation to go and put things right this year.”Park expects a tough game against Dee, with the Junior side eliminating Inverurie Locos, Aberdeen Reserves and Turrf United on route to the final.He also expects to have some banter ahead of the game with former team-mates Dean Lawrie and Jamie Watt – now with Dee.He added: “We played them in the final of the Shield last season and we know they are a good side. They’ve signed Dean Lawrie from ourselves so that will have strengthened them and they’ve started really well again this season.“Jamie Watt is co-manager and we know what type of guy he is.“He’ll have them fit and motivated and we look forward to playing them because it will be a good match.“There will be banter. I’m sure the texts will be flying back and forth before the game.“They will be looking forward to it just as us. It will be a good occasion on a Friday night.”Cove and Banks o’ Dee have met recently in a cup final.In February they faced one another in the final of the Aberdeenshire Shield.After a back and forth affair Cove eventually ran out - winners.Park featured that night, and he believes that John Sheran’s team can take confidence from beating Dee recently in a cup final.He said: “Last season can give us confidence, it was - and it was a good game.“We’re confident going into any game at the moment, having won  out of  in the league.“We’re playing well and we’ve got a strong squad so we are confident, but we know we’re in for a tough game.”

title: science matters week 36
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content and our journalists, so to get full access to all your local news updated -days-a-week – PLUS an e-edition of the Argyllshire Advertiser – subscribe today for as little as  pence per week.The multi-million dollar international trade in exotic pets has long been a bugbear of mine.Not only does it promote wild animals asfashion accessories, but it also allows potentially dangerous microbes to jump to, and cause epidemics in, other species including humans. What’s more, eventhey don’t mutate as occurred in the case outlined here,released into the wild either by design or mistake these foreigners can cause havoc to local ecosystems.In a letter to the scientic journal Nature in , a group of German scientists began ‘it has been rumoured that an unidentied crayfish…of marbled appearance and uncertain geographical origin that was introduced into the German aquarium trade in the mid s, is capable of unisexual reproduction ’.The authors ended by warning that: ‘This crayfish…could become a menace to European freshwater systems, as the release of even one specimen into the wild would be enough to found a population that might out-compete native crayfish’.Now,  years later, this all-female crayfish has escaped into the wild.  Identied as a descendent of the fresh water slough crayfish from Florida, it is now called the marbled crayfish or Marmokrebs. So far it has invaded the waterways of at least nine European countries as well as Japan and Madagascar. Unravelling its origin reveals that a unique macro-mutation must have occurred in a single slough crayfish egg probably caused by heat or cold shock whilst in transit from Florida to Germany for the pet market.The resulting female hatchling possessed three sets of chromosomes per celland the ability to produce clones of itself without a mate and at very high frequency.Because of its warm climate and abundant freshwater habitats, Madagascar has seen the most rapid colonisation with Marmokrebs. Millions of the animals have invaded the countries lakes, rice paddies and swamps and are threatening its seven endemic crayfish species.It is only a matter of time before this scenario is repeated in other locations, destroying valuable ecosystems and eliminating indigenous species.
